did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Smith-Fryer Family Collection chronicles the private and public lives of members of the Smith-Fryer family, resident in the Georgetown neighborhood from the late 1800s through the late 1900s.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: William Arthur Smith (1907-1991) was the son of Betty Hazel Fryer Smith (1887-1978) and Arthur Albin Smith (1882-1935), all lifelong Georgetown residents. William was a World War Two veteran, a paralegal, and a member of the Georgetown United Methodist Church, most notably serving as the church organist. Along with his siblings and mother, William was an active participant in local theater. He married Orpha Perkins Smith.

Betty Hazel Fryer Smith was William's mother. She was the daughter of William Robert Fryer (1856-1937) and Medora Batterson Bennett Fryer (1847-1919). Known as Hazel, she was a schoolteacher, a postmistress, and, after marriage, a newspaper journalist, besides being active in the Georgetown United Methodist Church and the Methodist Ladies Aid Society of Georgetown. She and her husband settled on West Church Street in Georgetown. Hazel's sister, who died young, was Edith Louise Fryer (1885-1899).

Arthur Albin Smith was William's father. He was the son of Marietta Albin Smith Sniffen (1861-1897) and William Smith. Arthur worked variously as a farm hand, a postman, a wire drawer at Gilbert & Bennett Mfg. Co., and a painter. He was a member of the Georgetown Volunteer Fire Department, the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, and was certified by the Connecticut Board of Examiners of Embalmers.

William's siblings were Edith Marie Smith (1909-2001), a lifelong Georgetown resident and manager and later vice-president at the Norwalk Savings Society; Ethel Louise Wellebil (1914-2001); and Elizabeth "Betty" Hazel Cowan (1922-2012), a graduate of the Methodist Hospital School of Nursing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the Smith-Fryer Family Collection is comprised of a large number of studio portraits and other photographs; items relating to the educational experiences of the Fryer and Smith children at the original Georgetown one-room schoolhouse, the Gilbert & Bennett School, and the Norwalk High School; and Betty Hazel Fryer Smith's diaries, newspaper articles, correspondence, and recipe book. Other notable categories include the correspondence of William Arthur Smith and various papers and ephemera related to World War Two. The collection also includes a number of greeting cards.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections
relatedmaterial.p: Additional correspondence of William Arthur Smith, written during his deployment during World War II, is with the Wilton Historical Society, as is his military uniform. His wartime photograph albums are in the Wilton History Room. Medora Batterson Bennett Fryer's portrait and a crazy quilt made by her are with the Wilton Historical Society. Additional Smith-Fryer family items may be found in other local archives and historical societies, including in Weston and Ridgefield.
